transcript.transcript: Chairman. On May 3rd, 1982. Mr. Schuman, I'd like to get your impressions of the Federal Music Project, because you were connected with it in various ways. I think particularly the Composers Forum. Who had some of your works were first tried out there? I believe so, I just would like to know get your evaluation of the importance. Or non-importance of the music project and so forth. Well, to answer your first question, I think it was very important. And I'm not talking about it just as on the humanitarian scale, obviously it was essential because it took musicians off the street and made it possible for them to to live, and that's too obvious even to go into. That was true of all of the Works Progress Administration programs. We know that. Yes. But as the first federally supported arts program is enormously important, even though it wasn't set up in order to support the arts, but in order to feed people. But whatever the motivation, it served the arts, as did the Writers Project and the Visual Arts Project and others. I first knew about it because I was a young composer. I was just starting my teaching career at Sarah Lawrence College. This was 1935, and I had come back from Salzburg, where I'd been studying, and I had a first symphony in my pocket, and I heard about the Composers Forum Laboratory, as it was called. I was under the direction of Ashley Pettis, whom I got to know very well subsequently, and I went to see Mr. Pettis, and I said I would be very happy if I could have a reading of this work, and I copied out the parts which any musician can tell you, at the very least before this process. But I didn't have the money to engage a copyist, and I said I'd like a reading of it just to rehearsal just so I can hear it. He said, well, that's impossible, we can't do that. But we can give you an evening of your works. I said, well, I'm just starting. I have a string quartet that I'm beginning, just the first quartet and some beginning choral pieces, but I certainly didn't expect anything as granted. And he said, well, it won't be an entire evening. It'll only be a half an evening. But we could certainly do the symphony. Asked me how long that played. I said about half an hour. And the string quartet and the choral pieces. So I said, well, that's fine, since I can't get a reading, I'll accept the concert. And there you had, in a nutshell, the exaggerated idea of it, because I was no more entitled to a half an evening or a quarter of evening than any other beginning composer. It was rather in a curious way. It was too much, much, too much. It would have done me much more good just to have had a reading. But I got to the first rehearsal, and you must remember, I'm not being unkind. I'm being absolutely accurate that you had some wonderful musicians in the WPA, but they were rather the exception because there were no real really there were no artistic standards in terms of consistency in an orchestra. You might get some people who had only played in a vaudeville band, who could rarely read the music required for a vaudeville act, who were totally incompetent when it came to reading a symphonic score, and others who had great experience. But it was a really a mixed bag, so you never knew just what you were going to get. And the the orchestra I got was something that they called the Gotham Orchestra. It was a small orchestra because my work was only for 18 instruments, as I recall. I called it a choreographic symphony because I had written some dance music, and I imagined motions to dance to it. And I went to the rehearsal and I was very young. I was 24, 25, and I'd only had a little choral performance in school and college, and I wasn't prepared for the fact that the musicians snickered and the better ones didn't snicker, but the ones who couldn't quite make it, or the ones who did most of the securing the conductor was the very worthy gentlemen. I'd never heard of him from him since, and some of the players were fine. I later heard from. Then I went to the rehearsal of the string quartet and they also snickered. Although there were a couple of two very good players in it, one ended up as the personnel manager of the Pittsburgh Symphony. Perhaps he still is, I don't know. And the other one was a very good violinist, but they were rather, um, put upon to do this new music and that it would be unfair to characterize their attitude as different from the attitude of the lay public, which is what you would expect from a lay public, but didn't expect it from musicians. Now, musicians today. And this is not the fault of the WPA, but musicians today are completely different. The young musicians today are absolutely astonishing. They can read anything. Just anything. There's so much more advanced and technical skills than they were when I was a young man. And usually people say this the other way around about the good old days. Not so. The young people today are extraordinary. Just extraordinary. And I don't mean that the best musicians in those days were any poorer than the best musicians today, because that's not true. The best are always the best. They're remarkable. But the average conservatory trained musician today that can play in a chamber music group is astonishing. They didn't have much chamber music. So those two works were not very well prepared. But the third work was very well prepared. It was prepared by Lehman Engel. Um, something with something he called the madrigals. So I got to know him very well. He remained very good friends over these years. So I'm not just a few weeks ago. We were both born in the same year, 1910. Wow. I'm hoping to see him. Oh, well, you can you can tell him that I said that was the only good performance that I have. Three those three and he will know what I'm talking about. And of course his performance was superb and I think I had met him before because I did a choral piece, won a prize, I got a recording on Columbia and publication and something else, and he was the conductor of the recording, so I knew him. At any rate, those pieces went very well, but the symphony was treated absolutely had a very hostile reaction, and so did the string quartet. And they both deserved it, because even if they had been very well performed, they were very minor student efforts, and it would have taken a very discerning musician to hear something in that music, as did Roy Harris and, and some other of the older composers, Aaron Copland, some of the others who became my champions. But as far as the public was concerned, they thought it was disgraceful and my poor family had just been married. I did what kind of a man did this lovely girl marry who You could write such terrible music, but it introduced me to the composers form. And despite the, um, despite the fact that the works were poorly played, it was an extraordinary experience to have because I had to get up afterwards and answer questions to the audience. It was the first time that I learned that I could talk on my feet, and that was very important to me, as it has been all throughout my life. And so I was enormously grateful for that experience. I got to know Ashley Pettis very well, as a matter of fact, got him a job at Sarah Lawrence College after I was fully ensconced teacher there. So I knew him, and I was very close to the problems of the Composers Forum and music, and in human terms, it was exemplary. Although of course it was bureaucratic, the same as any organization becomes, whether it's General Motors or the WPA. Anything that requires bureaucrats becomes bureaucratic. And the problem with it was that, on the one hand, it was too profligate and offering its faith as I just described. I certainly was not entitled to it, and it was too profligate in its choice of composers. Not just the young, untried composers, but almost anybody could have an appearance there. So it became, in that sense, a kind of vanity shop where you could go and get free performances. I think one prefers the real jungle world because it tells you really more what you like. Was that true all over the country where they had Composers Forum? I don't know anything about it around the country except New York. And you must remember in those days you could number the number the composers. If it sounds like a terrible pun, it isn't by the score. And now they're numbered in the thousands. Somebody told me that the 25,000 serious composers in the United States. No. Well, when I grew up, there were about 8 or 10 first line composers. And now I'd say we have about 8 to 10 first line composers. It seems not to go up in arithmetical proportion in any way. But then the Composers Forum also had another orchestra called the Federal Symphony Orchestra and large orchestras. Yes. And my next experience was a very interesting one. I submitted a work to a contest which was supposed to help Spanish democracy, which is a cause of all liberals, including this one wanted to support. And the contest promised performance, publication and recording. Well, that's pretty heady stuff. So I submitted my second symphony, which was after the first one, which I would do, and on the jury, I didn't know who the jury was going to be. The jury turned out to be Roy Harris, Aaron Copland, um, Wallingford Riegger Bernard Wagenaar, who was a teacher at the Juilliard School, and Roger sessions. It was quite a lineup. And they gave the award to my symphony, and it was not unanimous. Roger Sessions voted against it, and I dropped him a note, and I said it would mean a great deal to me if I could meet with you and find out why he didn't react as favorably to the others. And I spent a marvelous day with him in Princeton. By the end of the day, he was convincing me that it was a pretty good work, and I was convincing him that he was right. But at any rate, that was a wonderful experience. But what happened was the people who ran it were not Democrats at all. They were they were, um, communists who were trying to exploit this contest. So they didn't give a prize at all. They didn't give a prize. No. No performance, no recording, no nothing. They just wanted the publicity. So I wasn't going to sue a group that came out for Spanish democracy because that was everything. Everything is enough trouble. So I just took that as one of life's minor disappointments. Then it seemed major. But excuse me, this was part of the music project. Yes. No no no no. This contest had nothing to do with music. Oh, but I didn't get the performances, though. I then took it to the WPA editors, and I said, I hope that this work is worthy of performance. It certainly is. It won a contest judged by these men. So he arranged a performance of it with the Federal Symphony, and it was conducted by a man named Edgar Shenkman. Funny how these things work out, because years, ten years later, I was president of the Juilliard School, and he was on the conducting staff there. And these things just happen in a strange way. And he was a fine musician, but very few of the not very few, but at least half the people in the orchestra couldn't read the music. But again, it was a very difficult symphony to both to play and for the audience. And it was not at all successful, except it was successful with Aaron Copland, who came, and he brought it to the attention of Serge Koussevitzky, who was then the conductor of the Boston Symphony, who then scheduled. And that's how my career as a composer really began. But, um, I also heard Roy Harris's Second Symphony, which nobody else has played with. Alexander Smallens went to rehearsals of it. And you had when you had have conductors who had a progressive idea about music, you could get performances the way you have not been able to since. So it was a great service to composers. Now, I cited, I didn't mean to sound negative about the Composers Forum because I feel anything that negative about it. I'm trying to be analytical about it and at my own expense, because I certainly didn't deserve all that attention. Nevertheless, it was a remarkable thing to have, and you had a place that you could go. That's really what it was. Now, when the WPA was up to be abolished, when the when the recession depression was over, or long before that I was serving, I was still in my 20s, and the leading artists of the day who were then in their prime was Copeland and Martha Graham, Helen Hayes and a number of others that Walter Damrosch. I can't even remember their names. So I was Um, selected as a secretary. All unpaid, of course, to go to Washington and to speak to the chairman of the House Labor Committee, because the WPA was under the Labor Committee. And, of course, we're going to see if we couldn't get them to continue the program for the support of the arts. So I tell you, literally, because I will never forget this. And I've told him many times, and I tell it to you on tape, the head of the House Labor Committee, whose name I do not know, said to me, you guys want us to want us to support a bunch of goddamn toe dancers. And that's not the business of the United States Congress. That's as far as I got. So I brought these tidings home back to New York. And that was the end of that. And the project eventually folded. But it's never died. This composer's forum, as I said, still goes on this very day, the whole season. They even have a little publication. Now. I'll give you that shadow of his name before you leave today, Yeah. And you can drop in the note. It has a whole history. Oh. All starting then. And there have been many composers forums that that took flight from that idea. And also I'm not so sure that the WPA wasn't terribly important in and as a, as a seminal, seminal force in the eventual establishment of federal support for the arts. I can't prove that, except it awakened in me. My own reaction to it. And I was a very strong supporter, and I had some minor influence, along with a lot of other people of major influence in trying to promote federal support. Yes. Well, it really was the first time that apparently, that the federal government supported the arts. Absolutely. And now, of course, the support of the arts is so ingrained politically that they can cut it, but I doubt that they can cut it out. Yeah. You know, I don't want to make predictions. Yeah. Uh, I have asked several of the Musicians that I've interviewed, whether they thought it helped to further the career or preserve the careers of the musicians who played in the orchestras. I mean, would these musicians, if there had not been a WPA orchestra, have been forced to take other work and thereby get out of music and never go back? Do you think so? I can't answer it. I can speculate, but I can't answer it. My speculation is that most people never get out of music, whether they're successful or not. So of all the arts people are in, the arts are somehow sick. They'd rather starve doing that than make a little money selling insurance. Or some of them do that on the side. Oh, I thought, I can't answer the question. I don't think there are data to prove that one way or the other. I also I read that the New York, uh, WPA Symphony Orchestra, uh, did not introduce very many new works, did it? No, because the Chicago, the Chicago Probably one, you know. The Illinois Symphony. Is that the one with the. But Eisler had this idea. It always has to do with the accident of the person. Uh huh. Because they were noted for interest. I know that. I know that wasn't there a women's orchestra out there, too? But I've never. Yes. Not WPA. There was a women's symphony orchestra. In fact, a friend of mine organized that. Conducted it. Lillian gish. Yeah. I remember hearing about that. Uh huh. And just recently, when I was out there, I met the young man who conducts the civic orchestra. I can't think of his name. Oh, yes. And they sent me some tapes of some of my symphonies. I was not clear about how marvelous as performances were. The training orchestra in Chicago. Yes, yes. That's wonderful. They did very good. Oh, that's very good. Very good. He has a more liberal program in policy in Chicago, then. Uh huh. Um, well, I don't know about that. I guess that's probably true. When certain conductors like Alexander smaller, as I mentioned, a few others conducted it, you had more new music, but mostly they follow the usual patterns. Because musicians are like other people, they tend to do that. Mhm. Do you think that the music project had a lasting influence on music in this country in any way? I can't say that, I think so, no. Um, only if it were influential in causing federal support to come. In that sense I think it did. As a practice. Well, what about the introduction of of new music? Uh, was it true that most orchestras, before the project time played just more or less standard repertoire and were hesitant to introduce, uh, the new music because of their boards of trustees and So far. The situation has never changed. In the United States, exactly the same now. He's always in. His offices in Chicago this coming year. One of my friends tells me has a sudden spurt of some fresh repertory by the Chicago Orchestra, which he practices in that place in new music very, very, very, very, very rarely. And the Philharmonic has more, but it's not a great shining light in that regard. Nothing ever existed equal to Boston, because that was Mecca for 25 years. His offices are there. He sold out the house any place over the years. Aha! What about the building in Philadelphia? What about building new audiences for good music? I, I can only speculate. I don't think it did that at all. I think, for example, in theater, it did more to build a new audience. But I think when the project stopped and the audiences became regular commercial audiences? Yes. Well. Maybe. I mean, I mean, people couldn't afford to pay, uh, regular ticket prices. And so they went to federal music. Well, if you look. At people that go to the theater. If you look at people that go to the theater today, if you look at people that go to music today, um, and even the museums where there's a great, enormous Jerusalem of gold and silver, I'm not sure you could say that that percentage of the population is any larger than that. I doubt that the numbers might be larger. I don't think the percentages are. I just don't I don't see much change in attitudes. I really don't, and I've been around a long time. I just don't see any change in attitudes. Mhm. In fact, I would say that if anything it's worse because in American music we now have standard composers and composers who have written pieces that have been accepted into the repertoire. But even so, officers go year in and year out without paying even those people. That's true. Yeah. So it's, um. Um, I shocked someone, uh, last year by saying to him that the highlight of my life as a composer was when I finished the work and thought maybe it wasn't too bad, and that once it left my study, it was downhill all the way, because then I had to get a copy of that, and I went to an orchestra, and I had the pain of the rehearsal, and it went to the public. And that might be all right, or it might not, and the press might be bad. And it was. And I got that, and it was always had nothing to do with writing. It was just part of it. So that that composition as a profession is an absurdity as a, as a as a glory road, of course, without compare, but as a, as a profession. It's ridiculous. Uh. It's not really a profession. So that's the. And I'm, I'm you're speaking to someone who's not in the least bit embittered. I would have no reason to be. I don't mean in that sense at all. It's just. I'm just fucking. Tell me, do you happen to know whether when the theatre project did musical shows, did they get pit orchestras, for example, from the Music Project? I don't remember any musical shows that they did. They did The Living Newspaper, which often had musical company. Well, there was The Black Mikado and there was Osaka, and you sing and there were others, maybe not in New York, but we. Had. The. The Blitzstein. I don't think that was not the cradle of Rock was that was that was an amazing comic. Yeah, I think that was. Yeah. Well, it may have been. I'm not pins and needles was, uh, pins and needles. Um, but that was ladies garment work by the composer of one of our very, very closest friends. How we see them all the time. And, um, he'd be someone I never knew. But I don't think that that was. I don't think that was produced by the WPA in the ladies dormitory. Well, I thought, oh, maybe not. I don't know. Uh huh. But on the other hand, it wasn't Orson Welles and the Mercury Theater. I don't know whether that was involved with WPA or not in the beginning. Well, and the music for, uh, murder in the Cathedral? Yes. And he had his group, I believe, for he. Would know more. About that. And then, of course, there were, um, there were some other things that were just kind of, uh, some of that right away. And I don't know whether they I guess they had a pool of musicians that they laymen would know that. Yes. Because he was, you know, on the inside of it, I never was. He actually worked for the WPA. Yeah. With his. With his Vanderbilt singer. He was just marvelous, beautiful and everything. So he would be the one that would know all that. I'm glad you came to see him. And many, many composers had evenings at the forum, as you know. You know the whole list. But I wanted to say before, I want to be sure that I'm saying exactly on the record that the transcripts of those things are absolutely unreliable. We cook. It's always difficult to make a good transcript of anything. As you well know that those transcripts were so inaccurate and they just didn't make any sense. They sent me some was just impossible to correct. You know, it had no so little relationship to what took place. So they didn't have tape machines in those days. And even if they transcribed from tape, it's very difficult. I've had I've given oral histories to Yale and Columbia, and they have experts doing it, and it's amazing. Um, or the way the things come out. Um, what was the last one I got? I was talking about the Judith and Holofernes, and it came out as a hollow furnace. Oh. Hey. Is it working? Do you have a project which is created solely to take care of people who are out of work and give them the dignity of work, rather than putting them on a dole or a welfare payment and enabling them to work at their professions. And the sole purpose of it was not to promote those professions, but to supply employment. The wonder of it is that some of it fell short of the ideal. The wonder of it is that so many marvellous things happen to the arts when you look at the theatre. What happened to the theatre? What happened with music? What happened with the visual arts? It was one of the most astonishing of all the stories, of course. And there you actually see the heritage when you think of Ben Shahn. And you could mention a whole slew of people that came up through the WPA, which was really remarkable. So that there you had something that started with that as the goal to give employment and you had great riches flowing from it. Now you have endowments that exist not to give employment to promote the art. And I think it's only fair to say that the that the artistic standards are much, much higher because they're only thinking in terms of artistic criteria, not in terms of economic problems. Yeah. Uh, I have talked with musicians who think it might be a good idea if the government today, with the vast unemployment, we have now started some work projects, whether in the arts or in other in construction work. Well, you're getting into the theory of the government as the last employer of last resort. I would certainly think so. But with what's going on in Washington, I don't think they're thinking just that way. I'm sure they're not. If nothing is going to happen with the deficit and the economy going in the direction of it is, I don't think that at long last, the American people are going to be satisfied with wringing their hands. I think that they're going to prevail upon the Congress to take some corrective action, and I think we'll see that happen. Mhm. And we just have to hope that's not wishful thinking. But I can't imagine any other way. I think this country just can't sit by and let the present economic system, the point of view take over. Of course we haven't reached the stage yet where I, I imagine we have not where thousands and thousands of musicians are out of work and thousands of actors are out of work. I don't think we've reached all. These thousands of actors out of work. I'll tell you something about the WPA. Um, the only time that a composer is on the same economic level as the rest of the citizenry is during the depression. That I used to go to it all the time. And I also took composers I never heard about before. For example, David Diamond. Although I'm older than David by five years, he was much better established than I was a very young man. I went to hear him for the first time as Virgil Thompson, all sorts of people that I didn't know before. So it had a kind of excitement about it, because those who were interested, it never got huge audiences, but it always had a couple of hundred people. And I recall especially interesting. Well, then apparently that is the one thing of the music project that has lasted. Is that right? Well, it has lasted by name, and it started a tradition and it still goes on. Whether I don't think it has the same impact at all that it once had. But I think that has to do with the changing times. Plus the fact that every university has its own composers forum, but all the campuses have their own proposals and they put on festivals their own music. Did they have that before or did it all start with WPA? Well, I don't think there were so many composers teaching in schools at that time. That's a bit of development for the last 35 years or so. But some, as I say, there's been a whole explosion. There was no when I started the Juilliard String Quartet. I was 35 years ago. There were no other strings. American String quartet. That was my whole idea to create a first class American string quartet. There was one in Wisconsin, University of Wisconsin, the Polish Quartet. There was a musical quartet, the rock quartet, and maybe 1 or 2 others that come to mind. But there was no absolutely quartet of international significance that would do what I asked the Juilliard to do, which was to play old music as though a world premiere.

lines.line: # Significance of the Federal Music Project

> The speaker emphasizes the importance of the Federal Music Project, not only from a humanitarian perspective but also as the first federally supported arts program. Despite its primary goal being to provide employment rather than to support the arts directly, it significantly benefited the arts community by providing opportunities and support during a critical time.

metadata.title: Significance of the Federal Music Project
metadata.synopsis: The speaker emphasizes the importance of the Federal Music Project, not only from a humanitarian perspective but also as the first federally supported arts program. Despite its primary goal being to provide employment rather than to support the arts directly, it significantly benefited the arts community by providing opportunities and support during a critical time.

lines.line: # Early Involvement with the Composers Forum Laboratory

> The speaker recounts his early days as a composer when he first engaged with the Composers Forum Laboratory. Despite being a novice, he was offered a significant platform to present his work, which was both an overwhelming and enlightening experience. This opportunity marked the beginning of his professional journey in music.

metadata.title: Early Involvement with the Composers Forum Laboratory
metadata.synopsis: The speaker recounts his early days as a composer when he first engaged with the Composers Forum Laboratory. Despite being a novice, he was offered a significant platform to present his work, which was both an overwhelming and enlightening experience. This opportunity marked the beginning of his professional journey in music.

lines.line: > The speaker describes his experiences with the mixed quality of musicians in the WPA orchestras, highlighting the challenges of working with musicians of varying skill levels. These experiences ranged from unprofessional behaviors during rehearsals to moments of incompetence, reflecting the inconsistent standards within these orchestras.

metadata.title: Experiences with WPA Orchestras
metadata.synopsis: The speaker describes his experiences with the mixed quality of musicians in the WPA orchestras, highlighting the challenges of working with musicians of varying skill levels. These experiences ranged from unprofessional behaviors during rehearsals to moments of incompetence, reflecting the inconsistent standards within these orchestras.

lines.line: # Impact and Opportunities from the Composers Forum

> The speaker reflects on the significant impact the Composers Forum had on his career, providing him with early exposure and critical feedback. Despite some negative reactions to his work, the forum facilitated important connections and experiences that shaped his professional life.

metadata.title: Impact and Opportunities from the Composers Forum
metadata.synopsis: The speaker reflects on the significant impact the Composers Forum had on his career, providing him with early exposure and critical feedback. Despite some negative reactions to his work, the forum facilitated important connections and experiences that shaped his professional life.

lines.line: # Limitations of the WPA Music Projects

> The speaker critiques the WPA music projects for their bureaucratic nature and the lack of stringent selection criteria for composers, which sometimes led to a dilution of quality. He expresses a preference for the competitive nature of the 'real jungle world' which, according to him, offers a more accurate reflection of one's work.

metadata.title: Limitations of the WPA Music Projects
metadata.synopsis: The speaker critiques the WPA music projects for their bureaucratic nature and the lack of stringent selection criteria for composers, which sometimes led to a dilution of quality. He expresses a preference for the competitive nature of the 'real jungle world' which, according to him, offers a more accurate reflection of one's work.

lines.line: # Federal Support for the Arts Initiated by WPA

> The speaker discusses the groundbreaking role of the WPA as the first instance of federal support for the arts in the United States. He speculates on the lasting influence of the WPA in establishing a precedent for federal arts funding, which has become a politically ingrained aspect of government policy.

metadata.title: Federal Support for the Arts Initiated by WPA
metadata.synopsis: The speaker discusses the groundbreaking role of the WPA as the first instance of federal support for the arts in the United States. He speculates on the lasting influence of the WPA in establishing a precedent for federal arts funding, which has become a politically ingrained aspect of government policy.

lines.line: # Debating the WPA's Impact on Musicians' Careers

> The speaker explores whether the WPA orchestras helped preserve musicians' careers by providing them with work during tough economic times, thereby preventing them from leaving the music field. He also discusses the role of the WPA in introducing new music, noting that the conservative nature of music programming has not significantly changed over the years.

metadata.title: Debating the WPA's Impact on Musicians' Careers
metadata.synopsis: The speaker explores whether the WPA orchestras helped preserve musicians' careers by providing them with work during tough economic times, thereby preventing them from leaving the music field. He also discusses the role of the WPA in introducing new music, noting that the conservative nature of music programming has not significantly changed over the years.

children.text: # Significance of the Federal Music Project

> The speaker emphasizes the importance of the Federal Music Project, not only from a humanitarian perspective but also as the first federally supported arts program. Despite its primary goal being to provide employment rather than to support the arts directly, it significantly benefited the arts community by providing opportunities and support during a critical time.
# Early Involvement with the Composers Forum Laboratory

> The speaker recounts his early days as a composer when he first engaged with the Composers Forum Laboratory. Despite being a novice, he was offered a significant platform to present his work, which was both an overwhelming and enlightening experience. This opportunity marked the beginning of his professional journey in music.

> The speaker describes his experiences with the mixed quality of musicians in the WPA orchestras, highlighting the challenges of working with musicians of varying skill levels. These experiences ranged from unprofessional behaviors during rehearsals to moments of incompetence, reflecting the inconsistent standards within these orchestras.
# Impact and Opportunities from the Composers Forum

> The speaker reflects on the significant impact the Composers Forum had on his career, providing him with early exposure and critical feedback. Despite some negative reactions to his work, the forum facilitated important connections and experiences that shaped his professional life.
# Limitations of the WPA Music Projects

> The speaker critiques the WPA music projects for their bureaucratic nature and the lack of stringent selection criteria for composers, which sometimes led to a dilution of quality. He expresses a preference for the competitive nature of the 'real jungle world' which, according to him, offers a more accurate reflection of one's work.
# Federal Support for the Arts Initiated by WPA

> The speaker discusses the groundbreaking role of the WPA as the first instance of federal support for the arts in the United States. He speculates on the lasting influence of the WPA in establishing a precedent for federal arts funding, which has become a politically ingrained aspect of government policy.
# Debating the WPA's Impact on Musicians' Careers

> The speaker explores whether the WPA orchestras helped preserve musicians' careers by providing them with work during tough economic times, thereby preventing them from leaving the music field. He also discusses the role of the WPA in introducing new music, noting that the conservative nature of music programming has not significantly changed over the years.

story.title: William Schuman, May 3, 1982
story.description:
Interviewee: Schuman, William

Interviewer: Knoblauch-Franc, Marion

Occupation: Composer

Unit: Federal Music Project

Date: 1982-05-03

Length: 30 mins
